Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP)_1:
Patient Description 1:
    
    A 25-year-old male, with no history of lung disease or thoracic trauma, presented with an acute onset of severe chest pain, which he described as stabbing and rated 8/10 in intensity. The pain radiated to his right shoulder and intensified with inspiration, consistent with pleuritic chest pain. He also reported sudden shortness of breath and feelings of anxiety. On further inquiry, the patient mentioned a cough and vague symptoms of general malaise and fatigue. There is no evidence of tension pneumothorax or positive pressure ventilation.
Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP)_2:
Patient Description 2:
    
    A 30-year-old female patient, who is a non-smoker and has no history of lung disease, presented with sudden-onset right-sided chest pain. The pain was severe, with a stabbing quality (rated 9/10) and radiated to her right shoulder, increasing with each breath, suggestive of pleuritic pain. She also experienced a sudden shortness of breath and reported feelings of anxiety. The patient had a non-productive cough and described vague symptoms of malaise and fatigue. There is no evidence of tension pneumothorax or positive pressure ventilation.
Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP)_3:
Patient Description 3:
    
    A 22-year-old male, without a history of lung disease, presented with an acute onset of chest pain. He described the pain as severe (7/10), with a stabbing quality and noted its radiation to the right shoulder, which intensified during inspiration (pleuritic pain). The patient also reported sudden shortness of breath, along with feelings of anxiety. He had a non-productive cough and vague symptoms of general malaise and fatigue. There is no evidence of tension pneumothorax or positive pressure ventilation.
